I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will support the Asian Bond Markets Initiative (ABMI) by the 
Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) plus the People’s Republic of China (PRC), 
Japan, and the Republic of Korea (ROK) (collectively known as ASEAN+3) through support to the 
Cross-Border Settlement Infrastructure Forum (CSIF) to create an efficient regional settlement 
intermediary and promote more active intraregional financial investment.1 Since the CSIF’s 
establishment in 2013, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has served as its Secretariat and 
supported it by utilizing its convening power to help tackle regional challenges. 
 
2.  The TA is included in the work program of ADB’s Economic Research and Regional 
Cooperation Department (ERCD) for 2020, which is aligned with Strategy 2030’s sixth and 
seventh  operational  priorities:  “strengthening  governance  and  institutional  capacity”,  and 
“fostering regional cooperation and integration”.2 ADB will help developing member countries 
(DMCs) develop sound financial market infrastructures to support public management reforms 
and financial stability in the region under the sixth operational priority. ADB will also support 
catalyzing  and  mobilizing  financial  resources  for  development  by  developing  “quality 
infrastructure  required  for  attracting  private  sector  investment”,  and  “enhancing  domestic 
resource mobilization” by helping “channel the region’s savings more effectively for productive 
investments”, as stated under the seventh operational priority. The TA is also based on the 
ASEAN+3 ABMI Medium-Term Road Map, 2019–2022, endorsed at the ASEAN+3 Finance 
Ministers’ and Central Bank Governors’ Meeting (AFMGM+3) in Nadi, Fiji in May 2019.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  ASEAN+3  finance  ministers  established  the  ABMI  in  August  2003  to  boost  the 
development of local currency bond markets. Thanks to the efforts of the ASEAN+3 member 
economies, the local currency bond markets of the ASEAN+3 region have developed significantly 
and  the  region’s  financial  systems  have  become  more  resilient.  However,  despite  the 
development of the local capital market and high trade integration, the region still faces low 
intraregional portfolio investments and a large infrastructure investment gap as identified in the 
road map.4 The region’s large savings are returning via international financial centers such as 
London and New York. Such recycling of funds outside the region often creates unexpected 
volatility due to “herd behavior” or the “bandwagon effect” of financial markets. In particular, when 
an unexpected economic event affects certain emerging markets, it may also affect ASEAN+3 
member markets, regardless of the economic fundamentals of the ASEAN+3 member economies. 
  
4.  In  addition,  the  dollar  remains  the  dominant  medium  of  exchange  between  local 
currencies. Although intraregional trade accounts for more than 50% of trade in the ASEAN+3 
region, the dollar dominates more than 90% of intraregional financial transactions. This high 
reliance  on  the  dollar  in  cross-border  payments  can  trigger  a  shortage  of  dollar  liquidity, 
particularly  when  the  region  faces  an  unexpected  shock  such  as  the  coronavirus  disease 
pandemic. While the dollar remains the international vehicle currency, it is desirable to mitigate 
the problem at least for intraregional transactions. The region may be able to cope with liquidity 
 
1 CSIF members comprise staff from the ASEAN+3 central banks and central securities depositories (CSDs). Officials 
from the ministries of finance and securities and exchange commissions of ASEAN+3 may join as observers. 
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 August 2020. 
3 The road map is available at https://asianbondsonline.adb.org/documents/abmi_medium_term_road_map.pdf. 
4 The road map identified the following remaining challenges: (i) different levels of bond market development within the 
ASEAN+3 region, (ii) a large infrastructure investment gap, (iii) the need for sustainable finance, (iv) low intraregional 
portfolio investments, and (v)  the need for efficient resource mobilization for regional cooperation and integration.

2 
shortages by expanding the local currency collateral pool to be utilized for local currency–local 
currency cross-border transactions. 
 
5.  To address these problems, the CSIF agreed to establish a central securities depository 
(CSD)–real-time gross settlement (RTGS) linkage. These linkages are expected to facilitate 
intraregional portfolio investments and the use of local currency bonds as collateral, which had 
been locked in onshore markets. Linkages among national CSDs and central banks’ RTGS 
systems in different regional markets can realize cross-border, cross-currency delivery-versus-
payment (DVP) of cross-border securities transactions, as well as payment-versus-payment of 
local currencies to enable safe and efficient cross-border financial transactions in the region. Also, 
as  a  sign  of  growing  regional  cooperation  under  the  ABMI,  all  CSIF  members  will  adopt 
international standards, including ISO 20022 (possibly by 2023), as the basis for cross-border 
transactions.  Further,  amid  the  current  regulatory  trend  of  collateralization  in  cross-border 
transactions, the CSD–RTGS linkages may be able to free up the region’s domestic collateral 
pools for cross-border transactions. Based on such discussions under the CSIF, cross-border 
DVP between the Bank of Japan and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is expected to go live in 
2021 as the initial step in the linkages. 
 
6.  However, to expand the linkages further, the CSIF must pay more attention to recent 
technological advancements in financial transactions, such as distributed ledger technology and  
blockchain technology, which may influence the future technical architecture of the CSD–RTGS 
linkages and payment and settlement systems.5 Thus, the CSIF must stocktake and share 
experiences of the ASEAN+3 member markets. As the region is a global front-runner of such 
developments, it may be able to establish a new operational environment without significant costs.  
 
7.  The CSIF should also pay more attention to promoting a product and infrastructure design 
to catalyze cross-border trading. A collective investment scheme (CIS) and exchange traded 
funds may be able to channel the vast regional savings to ample investment opportunities within 
the region. Since the early 2010s, regional fund markets have become more integrated than ever 
with the launch of three intermarket fund-offering schemes: the ASEAN CIS, PRC–Hong Kong, 
China Mutual Recognition of Funds, and Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Asia Region Funds 
Passport (ARFP).6 These initiatives allow their nine regional member economies to sell funds to 
one another once a fund is registered as an offshore-offering fund. To respond proactively to 
these  concerted  regional  market  integration  efforts  accelerating  intraregional  financial 
transactions, the CSIF should examine the regional fund market infrastructures further.7  
 
8.  In addition, to ensure that the future market infrastructure design will facilitate cross-border 
collateral pooling, the CSIF should study necessary conditions for market infrastructures and 
central  banks  to  expand  their  collateral  eligibility  to  non-dollar  and  foreign  local  currency 
government bonds.  
 
 
5 Other relevant research initiatives include the Bank of Canada’s Project Jasper, the Monetary Authority of Singapore’s 
Project Ubin, and the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan’s joint Project Stella. Details are available at 
https://www.accenture.com/_acnmedia/pdf-99/accenture-cross-border-distributed-ledger-technologies.pdf  and 
https://www.ecb.europa.eu/paym/intro/publications/pdf/ecb.miptopical170101.en.pdf. 
6 The ASEAN CIS was launched among Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand in August 2014; the Mutual Recognition of 
Funds was launched between the PRC and Hong Kong, China in July 2015; and the ARFP was kick-started among 
Australia, Japan, the ROK, New Zealand, and Thailand in February 2016. Australia, Japan, New Zealand, and 
Thailand officially enforced the ARFP in 2019, and the ROK did so in May 2020. 
7 According to the Asia Fund Standardization Forum’s 2019 survey, CSDs run six centralized fund processing platforms 
in the PRC, Japan, ROK, Indonesia, Thailand, and Viet Nam.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: greater financial stability in the ASEAN+3 
region. Promoting regional cross-border financial transactions by developing and spreading well-
equipped market infrastructures and a local currency–local currency collateral pool will reduce the 
reliance on the dollar and United States Treasury, and serve as another regional safety net to 
support financial stability and resilience at the micro level in the region. 
 
10.  The TA will have the following outcome: regional risk management with cross-border 
transactions enhanced.8 Well-prepared market infrastructures such as the CSD–RTGS linkages 
enabling DVP and payment-versus-payment will realize cross-border, cross-currency financial 
transactions and substantially reduce cross-border settlement risk. These linkages will also 
address shortages of collateral and foreign banks’ access to local currency liquidity. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  As a continued regional cooperation effort, the TA will accumulate outputs stepwise. The 
TA consists of three outputs: (i) a CSIF report, (ii) reports to the ABMI Task Force 4 (TF4), and 
(iii) a linkage among the central banks and CSDs in ASEAN+3. 
 
12.  Output 1: A Cross-Border Settlement Infrastructure Forum report produced. The 
report will cover three topics: (i) a regional overview of recent technological advancements applicable 
to financial market infrastructures; (ii) a benchmark for product and market infrastructure design for 
regional fund markets and related infrastructures; and (iii) collateral eligibility for market infrastructures 
and central banks, and enabling factors to push local currency collateral utilization for cross-border 
financial transactions. Legal and market-related barriers will also be discussed. The CSIF report may 
be published electronically with the endorsement of the AFMGM+3. 
 
13.  Output 2: Reports to the Asian Bond Markets Initiative Task Force 4 produced. The 
CSIF will meet at least three times a year to discuss technological and market-related issues. 
Since government authorities play an essential role in market infrastructure development and 
ASEAN+3 government officials hold full ownership of the TA as mentioned in the Implementation 
Arrangements section below, ASEAN+3 government officials (in particular the ABMI TF4) will 
evaluate TA implementation and provide guidance if necessary. To that end, the TA will report 
progress on the CSIF activities at the semiannual ABMI TF4 meetings. 
 
14.  Output 3: A linkage among the central banks and central securities depositories in 
ASEAN+3  implemented  based  on  Cross-Border  Settlement  Infrastructure  Forum 
recommendations. As a regional safety net to support financial integration, at least one linkage 
will be implemented based on the agreement initially made between two CSIF members from 
advanced markets in line with the technological architecture and technical specification agreed 
through the CSIF. The first linkage will be a benchmark business case for the agreed linkage 
model. The TA will support its implementation by providing further technical specifications if 
necessary, and will share the implementation experience through a CSIF discussion to propagate 
the linkage further in the region. 
 
 
8  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the ROK 
e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  (EAKPF)  and  administered  by  ADB.9 The  key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
16.  According to para. 7 of the EAKPF Implementation Guidelines, the fund shall finance 
operational expenses related to eligible activities such as components of investment projects, 
stand-alone grant-financed activities, TA operations, and any other activities agreed upon by the 
Government of the ROK and ADB. It will not be used for (i) civil works, (ii) the procurement of 
large-scale equipment, (iii) permanent staffing costs, or (iv) the hiring of staff consultants, unless 
otherwise agreed between the Government of the ROK and ADB. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA. Staff at the Office of the Chief Economist and Director General 
of ADB’s ERCD will comprise the Secretariat of the CSIF and will organize CSIF meetings in close 
coordination with the CSIF Chairs. The ERCD will be directly responsible for (i) TA administration 
and supervision, management of consultants, and accomplishment of outputs; (ii) organizing 
meetings, trainings, or workshops and disseminating knowledge products; (iii) providing staff to 
act  as  resource  persons  for  conferences,  trainings,  or  workshops;  and  (iv)  monitoring  TA 
implementation. The TA will also be implemented in close coordination with ADB’s Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department, Southeast Asia Department, and East Asia 
Department. In particular, the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department’s 
Finance Sector Group and Regional Cooperation and Integration Thematic Group will be closely 
consulted. The TA will be implemented over 24 months from November 2020 to October 2022.  
 
18.  The Secretariat of the CSIF may organize regular CSIF meetings at least three times a year 
back-to-back with the ASEAN+3 Bond Market Forum. In addition, with support from CSIF members 
and experts, information on market regulations and practices as well as market infrastructures will 
be collected.10 All knowledge products under the TA will be disseminated through the CSIF meetings, 
ABMI task force meetings, AsianBondsOnline, and ADB’s other existing online platforms. 
 
19.  As the finance ministers and central bank governors of ASEAN+3, or ABMI government 
officials, hold full ownership of the TA, the TA will be evaluated by the ABMI TF4, consisting of 
officials from the ministries of finance and central banks of ASEAN+3 and currently co-chaired by 
the ROK and the Philippines. Official ABMI task force meetings will be held at least semiannually 
to monitor the CSIF’s progress, which will be reported to the ASEAN+3 Finance and Central Bank 
Deputies’ meeting for further guidance. The outputs of the CSIF will be reported to the AFMGM+3 
for their endorsement. 
 
20.  In the event that ADB staff act as resource persons for the purpose of effectiveness, travel 
costs are charged to the TA, but their salaries and benefits are absorbed by the internal 
administrative expenses budget.11

22.  Consulting services. The TA will require 12 person-months of international and 24 
person-months of national individual consultancy services: (i) 9 person-months for a lead payment 
and settlement specialist, (ii) 1 person-month for a payment and settlement specialist, (iii) 1 
person-month for a fund market system specialist, (iv) 1 person-month for an economics and 
finance editor, and (v) 24 person-months for a program coordinator (ADB headquarters). ADB will 
engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.12 
 
23.  Cofinancier requirements. The TA will comply with the requirements in the EAKPF 
Implementation Guidelines, such as the notification of TA implementation milestones, record 
keeping, reporting, monitoring and evaluation, audits, and the EAKPF’s visibility.13 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 
to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund 
for Promoting Cross-Border Financial Transactions in the ASEAN+3 Region: Support to the 
Cross-Border Settlement Infrastructure Forum under the Asian Bond Markets Initiative Medium-
Term Road Map, 2019–2022, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
